identificationModule.briefTitle: Effects of Blood Flow Restriction (BFR) Therapy on ACL Graft Maturation
identificationModule.officialTitle: Effects of Blood Flow Restriction (BFR) Therapy on Early Anterior Cruciate Ligament (ACL) Graft Maturation

descriptionModule.briefSummary: This is a study comparing the effects of blood flow restriction (BFR) therapy on the maturation of the Anterior Cruciate Ligament (ACL) graft after reconstruction surgery compared to physical therapy without the use of BFR.
descriptionModule.detailedDescription:
The study will be a randomized controlled trial to compare outcomes between physical therapy with BFR and physical therapy without BFR on the ACL graft maturation following reconstruction surgery. BFR therapy will begin as early as 2 weeks after surgery. The initial 2 weeks after surgery, or prior to initiation of BFR, will consist of the physical therapy following the surgeon's postoperative protocol.

To be considered for participation in this study, patients must be 18 years and older undergoing primary ACL reconstruction. In addition, patients must meet several inclusion/exclusion criteria to be randomized and included in this study.

armGroups.label: Physical Therapy with BFR
armGroups.description: Participants will begin BFR therapy as early as 2 weeks after surgery. The initial 2 weeks after surgery, or prior to initiation of BFR will consist of the physical therapy following the surgeon's postoperative protocol.

armGroups.label: Physical Therapy without BFR
armGroups.description: Participants will undergo standard physical therapy following the surgeon's postoperative protocol.

interventions.name: Blood Flow Restriction Therapy
interventions.description: BFR is a rehabilitation method that involves wearing a tight band around the exercising extremity to briefly limit blood flow while doing light weight exercises. The response is similar to heavy weight training or lifting but without the stress on the extremity that is still healing from surgery. Will be given after 2 weeks standard postoperative physical therapy per surgeon's ACL reconstruction protocol following surgery.

interventions.name: Standard Postoperative Physical Therapy
interventions.description: This is the surgeon's standard postoperative physical therapy protocol after ACL reconstruction.

primaryOutcomes.measure: Difference in MRI imaging of Graft
primaryOutcomes.description: Graft ligamentization or maturation on MRI using T2 mapping

primaryOutcomes.measure: Difference in Quadriceps Volume & Cross-sectional Area
primaryOutcomes.description: Quadriceps muscle atrophy measured on MRI with quadriceps cross-sectional area
Muscle measurement determined with measuring tape for thigh circumference

secondaryOutcomes.description: Measurement of knee extension and flexion torque at 180° and 300°/sec using the isokinetic dynamometer
Patient reported assessment of current level of pain from no pain to worst imaginable
Patient reported outcome measure of function. 0-100% scale with 100% being normal

Patient reported outcome measure of symptoms, sports activity \& knee function. 0-100 points with 0 (lowest level of function or highest level of symptoms) to 100 points (highest level of function and lowest level of symptoms)

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion Criteria:

* Ages 18 or older, all gender
* Patients receiving any type of ACL graft, either autograft or allograft, and any type of tissue

Exclusion Criteria:

* Patients who do not meet the the comprehensive BFR screening criteria based on predetermined contraindications and precautions
* Patients undergoing any additional concomitant ligament repair or reconstruction at the same surgery
* Revision procedures
* Patients unable to lay still in an MRI scanner
* Patients receiving treatment outside Stanford
* Patients undergoing concomitant meniscus treatment that restricts patients' weight bearing or prolongs their immobilization compared to their surgeons standard postoperative ACL reconstruction protocol
* Patients who are unble to lay still in an MRI scanner
* Patients with a torn ACL or previous ACL reconstruction in the contralateral knee
